passage_text: The kittens,however will be born with alot of problems becouse their parents have the same blood. It would be like you having a baby with your brother/sister. Thats becouse cats have Pheremones. Pheremones are chemicals given off by your body that can attract or repulse a potential mate. Member 494894 answered on 1/12/08.

Yes cats can and will mate with siblings-they don't make choices about their reproduction like humans do, there's only hormones and instinct. Any kittens produced from a brother/sister pairing will be at greatly elevated risk for genetic deformities and diseases. Get the cats fixed and avoid the problem altogether.

Cats, when sexually mature, will mate with the first available cat, even if they are related. Unlike humans, cats, dogs and other animals are not bound by social taboos o … r realise that breeding with family members can result in birth defects and deformities.

Theoretically, a female cat can remain in heat for up to 21 days. She can mate with more than one male during that period of time and can have a litter of kittens which contains kittens from one male AND kittens from the other male.

Female cats in heat would be receptive to the attention of any male cat. In a multi-cat household where the cats are not allowed t go out, the cats would look no further for a potential sexual mate. The cats would mate with the other pet cats.

Furthermore, when a male cat becomes sexually mature, he will also try to mate with his mother, if she is around. Unlike humans -- well, most humans, anyway -- cats (and dogs) do not recognize that having sex with members of your family is a major no-no.

Yes, sexually mature sibling cats can and will mate with each other, if you let them. Letting them mate with each other is, of course, a very, very bad idea, as inbreeding among any species causes numerous birth defects and deformities.
